sect1.title: Names of example items
sect1.para: This section summarizes conventions for creating generic names for objects in documentation. At least some of the following names should be provided through entities. See also .

sect2.title: Domains
sect2.para: Use and as example domains. Both domains were registered for use in documentation.

sect2.title: Host names
sect2.para: Use objects of the solar system: For the most important system, use sun. For other systems, use the names of planets such as earth or mars.

sect2.title: IPv4 addresses
sect2.para: Use addresses from the class C subnet 192.168.255.0 for examples. That is, replace the final 0 by any integer between 0 and 255. To create examples using a larger setup, use addresses from the private network ranges. For more information, see .

sect2.title: IPv6 addresses
sect2.para: Use addresses from the subnet 2001:0db8::/32 for examples. That is, after the 2001:0db8: prefix, add six four-digit numbers, each separated by a colon on both sides. Each of the hexadecimal digits may have a value between 0 and f. A valid example URL is 2001:0db8:0123:4567:89ab:cdef:1234:5678. For more information, see .

sect2.title: Users
sect2.para: For example users, use free-software mascots, such as Tux (Linux Kernel), Wilber (The GIMP), Geeko (&suse;), Foxkeh (Firefox), Konqi (KDE), or Duke (Java). In prompts, use the lowercase version of these names.
